figure.figDesc: Tracking classification indices and the same difference score algorithm used in the IAT.These new difference scores can be easily calculated using the FT-IAT, and offer a new cognitively linked behavioral measure of implicit cognition. The approach provides insights into cognitive familiarity between category/attribute pairings similar to the original IAT. In-flight processing analogies to D-score gives convergent evidence of IAT effects that can be analyzed for trends in larger scale research programs. RT-based difference scores like those used in the IAT have been central to many mental chronometry approaches like the Stroop test and the go/no-go task. However this proposed metrics offer a scalable and low-cost alternative for assessing implicit cognition with rich processing data recorded from the start of a trial until a final selection is made Three new approaches to d-score analysis, namely absolute deviation, movement, and area under the curve, have been proposed within the framework of the FT-IAT. These measures provide whole trial evaluations of deviation from an idealized path. While the utility of these d-scores in the assessment of cognitive bias has yet to be fully explored, each may offer unique insights into the strength of associations endorsed by individuals and provide a more more robust measure of bias when considered in conjunction. Further research is necessary to determine the specific meaning of these metrics in the context of individual cognition. However, it is clear that new approaches to understanding implicit bias warrant consideration in future research.Considering current evidence, Average Deviation(Koop & Johnson, 2013) may be the most promising spatial variable for calculating individual d-scores from trajectory indices, as it demonstrates higher internal reliability and agrees with D-score direction and magnitude as an indication of bias on this data set. Additionally, the movement metric, which is closely related to response time D-score, has demonstrated high internal consistency through split-half corelations evidencing that movement may be a promising replacement for response time in future FT-IAT investigations.

figure.head: Table 0 .
figure.figDesc: Trajectory indices definitions and source literature

The current practices in use for analyzing Finger Tracking data have been outlined elsewhere by the creators of mousetrap, a proprietary package in the R programming language developed for mousetracking experiments(Wulff, Kieslich, Henninger, Haslbeck & Schulte-Mecklenbeck, 2021). The mousetrap environment makes available a culmination of many years of mousetracking methodology and is well suited to do finger tracking analysis. One common approach is to first assess the homogeneity of the data set. To determine if there is heterogeneous behavior, researchers often examine bimodality in trajectory indices and use difference heatmap plots to identify differences between experimental conditions. Bimodality tests are not the most robust statistical tests they can help identify which analysis approach to
figure.note: take. If there is evidence of sample heterogeneity a trajectory types analysis can be conducted to see if the frequency of types varies significantly between conditions.

figure.figDesc: ParticipantsA total of 73 responses were collected from a pilot survey by completing a Qualtrics questionnaire. After eliminating incomplete submissions and false start entries, a total of 22 participants completed useable data for the entire survey. Of these 22 participants, 14 completed , only two were left-handed reasoning that the balanced block design would mitigate any handedness effects. The focus of this investigation is on the results of the FT-IAT, as it had the highest sample size due to its block design.
figure.note: a Big Five Personality Survey, 18 completed a Finger Tracking Implicit Association Test, and 15 completed a section on entomophobia. Out of the total pool of participants, only 8 completed usable data for analysis in all sections. Out of the 22 participants who completed the survey

figure.figDesc: All materials are on record with the Stanford IRB and the research is being conducted by two doctoral students in the Stanford Graduate School of Education.All participants completed the full set of IAT prompts in a single session, administered remotely via the online platform Qualtrics. The study utilized a touchscreen device and included three Finger Tracking tasks, two Likert-type surveys that paralleled the Finger Tracking procedures, and a brief demographic questionnaire, a common practice in research. The survey took approximately 30 minutes for each participant to complete. The survey items were administered using Qualtrics survey software, and the Finger Tracking tasks were coded by
figure.note: Ethan Roy and integrated into the Qualtrics environment using Pavlovia (Sauter, Draschkow & Mack, 2020).

figure.figDesc: Based on these results, we found no evidence of bimodality and therefore conclude that a types analysis is not likely to be appropriate for our data.

row.cell: Since visual inspection gave cause for a test of bimodality, a check was performed on the
distribution of classification indices for evidence of bimodality. One commonly used method for
detecting bimodality is Hartigans' dip statistic, where a low value D between [0, 1) indicates
unimodality and significance is reported as a p-value. Applying Hartigans' dip statistic to test for
bimodality obtained the following results: for RT, D = 0.0084447, p-value = 0.4108; for
movement, D = 0.0048857, p-value = 0.9923; for AUC, D = 0.0045218, p-value = 0.9947; for
